column1: 9~9~2016-05-26~2016-05-26~Advance Monthly Sales for Retail and Food Services~True~http://www.census.gov/retail/~"The U.S. Census Bureau conducts the Advance Monthly Retail Trade and Food Services Survey to provide an early estimate of monthly sales by kind of business for retail and food service firms located in the United States. Each month
column2: questionnaires are mailed to a probability sample of approximately 4
column3: 700 employer firms selected from the larger Monthly Retail Trade Survey. Advance sales estimates are computed using a link relative estimator. For each detailed industry
column4: we compute a ratio of current-to previous month weighted sales using data from units for which we have obtained usable responses for both the current and previous month. For each detailed industry
column5: the advance total sales estimates for the current month is computed by multiplying this ratio by the preliminary sales estimate for the previous month (derived from the larger MRTS) at the appropriate industry level. Total estimates for broader industries are computed as the sum of the detailed industry estimates. The link relative estimate is used because imputation is not performed for most nonrespondents in MARTS. For a limited number of nonresponding companies that have influential effects on the estimates
column6: sales may be estimated based on historical performance of that company. The monthly estimates are benchmarked to the annual survey estimates from the Annual Retail Trade Survey once available. The estimates are adjusted for seasonal variation and holiday and trading day differences. Additional information on MARTS and MRTS can be found on the Census Bureau website at: www.census.gov/retail.

52~52~2016-05-26~2016-05-26~Z.1 Financial Accounts of the United States~True~http://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/z1/~"The Financial Accounts (formerly known as the Flow of Funds accounts)  are a set of financial accounts used to track the sources and uses of funds by sector. They are a component of a system of macroeconomic accounts including the National Income and Product accounts (NIPA) and balance of payments accounts
column2: all of which serve as a comprehensive set of information on the economy’s performance.(1) Some important inferences that can be drawn from the Financial accounts are the financial strength of a given sector
column3: new economic trends
column4: changes in the composition of wealth
column5: and development of new financial instruments over time.(1)

column1: Sectors are compiled into three categories: households
column3: and banks. The sources of funds for a sector are its internal funds (savings from income after consumption) and external funds (loans from banks and other financial intermediaries). (1) Funds for a given sector are used for its investments in physical and financial assets. Dividing sources and uses of funds into two categories helps the staff of the Federal Reserve System pay particular attention to external sources of funds and financial uses of funds.(2) One example is whether households are borrowing more from banks—or in other words
column4: whether household debt is rising. Another example might be whether banks are using more of their funds to provide loans to consumers. Transactions within a sector are not shown in the accounts; however
column5: transactions between sectors are.(2) Monitoring the external flows of funds provides insights into a sector’s health and the performance of the economy as a whole.

column1: Data for the Financial accounts are compiled from a large number of reports and publications
column2: including regulatory reports such as those submitted by banks
column3: tax filings
column4: and surveys conducted by the Federal Reserve System.(2) The Financial accounts are published quarterly as a set of tables in the Federal Reserve’s Z.1 statistical release.

column2: Albert M. “The U.S. Flow of Funds Accounts and Their Uses.” Federal Reserve Bulletin
column3: July 2001; http://www.federalreserve.gov/pubs/bulletin/2001/0701lead.pdf.

column1: (2)	Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. “Guide to the Flow of Funds Accounts.” 2000

column1: 242~242~2016-05-26~2016-05-26~Recession Indicators Series~False~http://www.oecd.org/std/leading-indicators/oecdcompositeleadingindicatorsreferenceturningpointsandcomponentseries.htm~"These time series are an interpretation of US Business Cycle Expansions and Contractions data provided by The National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER) at http://www.nber.org/cycles/cyclesmain.html and Organisation of Economic Development (OECD) Composite Leading Indicators: Reference Turning Points and Component Series data provided by the OECD at http://www.oecd.org/std/leading-indicators/oecdcompositeleadingindicatorsreferenceturningpointsandcomponentseries.htm. Our time series are composed of dummy variables that represent periods of expansion and recession. The NBER identifies months and quarters
column3: of turning points without designating a date within the period that turning points occurred. The dummy variable adopts an arbitrary convention that the turning point occurred at a specific date within the period. The arbitrary convention does not reflect any judgment on this issue by the NBER's Business Cycle Dating Committee or the OECD. A value of 1 is a recessionary period
column4: while a value of 0 is an expansionary period.

column1: The recession shading data that we provide initially comes from the source as a list of dates that are either an economic peak or trough. We interpret dates into recession shading data using one of three arbitrary methods. All of our recession shading data is available using all three interpretations. The period between a peak and trough is always shaded as a recession. The peak and trough are collectively extrema. Depending on the application
column3: both individually and collectively
column4: may be included in the recession period in whole or in part. In situations where a portion of a period is included in the recession
column5: the whole period is deemed to be included in the recession period.

column3: is to show a recession from the midpoint of the peak through the midpoint of the trough for monthly and quarterly data. For daily data
column4: the recession begins on the 15th of the month of the peak and ends on the 15th of the month of the trough. Daily data is a disaggregation of monthly data. For monthly and quarterly data
column5: the entire peak and trough periods are included in the recession shading. This method shows the maximum number of periods as a recession for monthly and quarterly data. The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis uses this method in its own publications.

column3: is to show a recession from the period following the peak through the trough (i.e. the peak is not included in the recession shading
column4: but the trough is). For daily data
column5: the recession begins on the first day of the first month following the peak and ends on the last day of the month of the trough. Daily data is a disaggregation of monthly data. The trough method is used when displaying data on FRED graphs.

column3: is to show a recession from the period of the peak to the trough (i.e. the peak is included in the recession shading
column4: but the trough is not). For daily data
column5: the recession begins on the first day of the month of the peak and ends on the last day of the month preceding the trough. Daily data is a disaggregation of monthly data."

column1: The survey is sent on the first business day of each month to the same pool of about 150 business executives
column3: in the region's service sector. In a typical month
column4: about 100 responses are received by around the tenth of the month when the survey closes.

column1: Respondents come from a wide range of industries outside of the manufacturing sector

column1: 365~365~2016-05-26~2016-05-26~Primary Commodity Prices~False~https://www.imf.org/en/Research/commodity-prices~Benchmark prices which are representative of the global market. They are determined by the largest exporter of a given commodity. Prices are period averages in nominal U.S. dollars. Price indices are based in 2005 (average of 2005 = 100).

366~366~2016-05-26~2016-05-26~Asia and Pacific Regional Economic Outlook~False~http://data.imf.org/?sk=ABFF6C02-73A8-475C-89CC-AD515033E662~APD Regional Economic Outlook provides information on recent economic developments and prospects for countries in Asia and the Pacific.

368~368~2016-05-26~2016-05-26~Middle East and Central Asia Regional Economic Outlook~False~http://data.imf.org/?sk=4CC54C86-F659-4B16-ABF5-FAB77D52D2E6&ss=1390030109571~"The IMF’s Middle East and Central Asia Department (MCD) countries and territories comprise Afghanistan
column3: Armenia
column4: Azerbaijan
column5: Bahrain

column1: More information about forecasting methodology is available at http://data.imf.org/?sk=4CC54C86-F659-4B16-ABF5-FAB77D52D2E6&ss=1390288795525.
The base year for constant prices differs by nation. More information is available at https://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2015/02/weodata/co.pdf."

369~369~2016-05-26~2016-05-26~Sub-Saharan Africa Regional Economic Outlook~False~http://data.imf.org/?sk=5778F645-51FB-4F37-A775-B8FECD6BC69B~The Sub-Saharan Africa Regional Economic Outlook provides information on recent economic developments and prospects for countries in Sub-Saharan Africa. Data for the REO for Sub-Saharan Africa is prepared in conjunction with the semi-annual World Economic Outlook exercises
column2: spring and fall. Data are consistent with the projections underlying the WEO. REO aggregate data may differ from WEO aggregates due to differences in group membership. Composite data for country groups are weighted averages of data for individual countries. Arithmetic weighted averages are used for all concepts except for inflation and broad money
column3: for which geometric averages are used. PPP GDP weights from the WEO database are used for the aggregation of real GDP growth
column4: real non-oil GDP growth
column5: real per capita GDP growth
column9: claims on the nonfinancial private sector
column10: and real and nominal effective exchange rates. Aggregates for other concepts are weighted by GDP in U.S. dollars at market exchange rates.

column1: 370~370~2016-05-26~2016-05-26~Financial Access Survey~False~http://data.imf.org/?sk=E5DCAB7E-A5CA-4892-A6EA-598B5463A34C~The Financial Access Survey is the sole source of global supply-side data on financial inclusion
column2: encompassing internationally-comparable basic indicators of financial access and usage. In addition to providing policy makers and researchers with annual geographic and demographic data access on basic consumer financial services worldwide
column3: the survey is the data source for the G-20 Basic Set of Financial Inclusion Indicators endorsed by the G-20 Leaders at the Los Cabos Summit of June 2012.

column1: 371~371~2016-05-26~2016-05-26~Hornstein-Kudlyak-Lange Non-Employment Index~True~https://www.richmondfed.org/research/national_economy/non_employment_index~The Hornstein-Kudlyak-Lange Non-Employment Index (NEI) is an alternative to the standard unemployment rate that includes all non-employed individuals and accounts for persistent differences in their labor market attachment. It provides a more comprehensive reading of labor market health and is based on research first published by Richmond Fed economists Andreas Hornstein and Marianna Kudlyak
column2: and McGill University economist Fabian Lange.

column1: 372~372~2016-05-26~2016-05-26~Chicago Fed Survey of Business Conditions~True~https://www.chicagofed.org/publications/cfsbc/index~The Chicago Fed Survey of Business Conditions (CFSBC) is a survey of business contacts conducted to support the Seventh Federal Reserve District’s contribution to the Beige Book.

373~373~2016-05-26~2016-05-26~GDP-Based Recession Indicator Index~True~http://econbrowser.com/recession-index~This index measures the probability that the U.S. economy was in a recession during the indicated quarter.  It is based on a mathematical description of the way that recessions differ from expansions.

374~374~2016-05-26~2016-05-26~Texas Manufacturing Outlook Survey~True~https://www.dallasfed.org/research/surveys/tmos.aspx~The Texas Manufacturing Outlook Survey (TMOS) is a monthly survey of area manufacturers. Firm executives report on how business conditions have changed for a number of indicators
column3: new orders
column4: employment
column5: prices and company outlook. Respondents are also asked to report on how they perceive broader economic conditions to have changed (general business activity). For all questions
column6: participants are asked whether the indicator has increased
column7: decreased or remained unchanged. Answers cover changes over the previous month and expectations for activity six months into the future. Participants are given the opportunity to submit comments on current issues that may be affecting their business.

column1: 376~376~2016-05-26~2016-05-26~Texas Service Sector Outlook Survey~True~http://dallasfed.org/microsites/research/surveys/tssos/index.cfm~"The Texas Service Sector Outlook Survey (TSSOS) is a monthly survey of area service sector businesses. Firm executives report on how business conditions have changed for a number of indicators such as revenue
column3: prices and company outlook. Respondents are also asked to report on how they perceive broader economic conditions to have changed (general business activity). For all questions
column4: participants are asked whether the indicator has increased
column5: decreased or remained unchanged. Answers cover changes over the previous month and expectations for activity six months into the future. Participants are given the opportunity to submit comments on current issues that may be affecting their business.

column1: About 230 service-providing firms regularly participate in TSSOS
column2: which began collecting data in January 2007. Respondents are broadly representative of service-producing industries in the private sector. TSSOS includes a breakout for respondents in the retail and wholesale sectors
column3: called the Texas Retail Outlook Survey (TROS). TSSOS questionnaires are electronically transmitted to respondents in the middle of each month
column4: and answers are collected over seven business days. TROS respondents receive a slightly different questionnaire
column5: but the survey period and processing is the same.

column1: The service sector makes up the bulk of the Texas economy
column2: accounting for 59 percent of private-sector activity and employing close to 7 million workers. Retailers and wholesalers make up 12 percent of Texas output and account for 1.6 million jobs. Despite the service sector's prominence
column3: there are few timely measures of changes in service sector activity at the state level. TSSOS fills this regional data gap. TSSOS and its retail component
column4: TROS
column5: are highly correlated with monthly changes in regional economic indicators such as private service sector employment
column6: retail employment and retail sales (see related article below)."

column1: 377~377~2016-05-26~2016-05-26~Texas Retail Outlook Survey~True~http://dallasfed.org/microsites/research/surveys/tssos/index.cfm#tros~"The Texas Retail Outlook Survey (TROS) is a monthly survey of area service sector businesses
column2: specifically retail businesses. Firm executives report on how business conditions have changed for a number of indicators such as revenue
column3: employment
column4: prices and company outlook. Respondents are also asked to report on how they perceive broader economic conditions to have changed (general business activity). For all questions
column5: participants are asked whether the indicator has increased
column6: decreased or remained unchanged. Answers cover changes over the previous month and expectations for activity six months into the future. Participants are given the opportunity to submit comments on current issues that may be affecting their business.

column1: About 230 service-providing firms regularly participate in TSSOS
column2: which began collecting data in January 2007. Respondents are broadly representative of service-producing industries in the private sector. TSSOS includes a breakout for respondents in the retail and wholesale sectors
column3: called the Texas Retail Outlook Survey (TROS). TSSOS questionnaires are electronically transmitted to respondents in the middle of each month
column4: and answers are collected over seven business days. TROS respondents receive a slightly different questionnaire
column5: but the survey period and processing is the same.

column1: The service sector makes up the bulk of the Texas economy
column2: accounting for 59 percent of private-sector activity and employing close to 7 million workers. Retailers and wholesalers make up 12 percent of Texas output and account for 1.6 million jobs. Despite the service sector's prominence
column3: there are few timely measures of changes in service sector activity at the state level. TSSOS fills this regional data gap. TSSOS and its retail component
column4: TROS
column5: are highly correlated with monthly changes in regional economic indicators such as private service sector employment
column6: retail employment and retail sales (see related article below)."

column1: 382~382~2016-05-26~2016-05-26~Real Trade-Weighted Value of the Dollar by U.S. State~True~https://www.dallasfed.org/research/econdata/rtwvd.aspx~These indexes calculate the inflation-adjusted value of the U.S. dollar against the currencies of countries to which the state exports. The real exchange rates are aggregated across countries for each state using the annual average export share to the country. For the most recent year where export share data is not available
column2: the prior year' number is used instead. The indexes should allow analysts to more precisely identify the exchange rate movements that most affect demand for a state's exports. For more information visit http://www.dallasfed.org/research/econdata/rtwvd.cfm.

column1: 383~383~2016-05-26~2016-05-26~Market Value of U.S. Government Debt~True~http://www.dallasfed.org/research/econdata/govdebt.cfm~For many uses
column2: market value more accurately represents the debt burden faced by the U.S. government than the par value. The par value of government debt
column3: which is reported by the U.S. Treasury Department
column4: reflects interest rates at the time the debt was issued while the market value is adjusted to reflect market interest rates as of the observed period. Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas researchers calculate the market value of U.S. government debt series.

column1: 386~386~2016-05-26~2016-05-26~GDPNow~True~https://www.frbatlanta.org/cqer/research/gdpnow.aspx?panel=1~"The growth rate of real gross domestic product (GDP) is a key indicator of economic activity
column2: but the official estimate is released with a delay. The Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta's GDPNow forecasting model provides a ""nowcast"" of the official estimate prior to its release."

column1: 391~391~2016-05-26~2016-05-26~Personal Consumption Expenditures by State~True~https://www.bea.gov/data/consumer-spending/state~Release contains both per capita personal consumption expenditures and personal consumption expenditures by state. This data set also contains sector based data each state.
